image.altText: Albanese stands speaking to media from a courtyard.

items.synopsis: The federal government has suffered its first major defeat in the Senate, with the Greens and Coalition uniting to reject Labor's centrepiece housing policy.

title.children: Federal government gains early election trigger as Senate rejects housing bill

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

items.synopsis: A 31-year-old man pleads guilty to choking two teenagers in retaliation for a slapping game gone wrong, in which he believed his stepson was hurt.

title.children: Canberra man pleads guilty to choking two 13-year-olds in retaliation for slapping game gone wrong

image.altText: A young boy wearing a dark blue shirt reading a book.

items.synopsis: The report by Equity Economics found literacy levels in the ACT are worse than 20 years ago. There are now calls to overhaul how reading is taught in public schools.

title.children: Calls to overhaul how literacy is taught in Canberra public schools after report finds many students behind in reading

image.altText: The backs of three police officers who are running through a hallway with guns drawn.

items.synopsis: The $107 million funding boost comes after continued complaints about the ACT having the lowest number of police per capita in the country.

title.children: Union warns 126 extra police isn't enough to address Canberra's officer shortfall

image.altText: An overview of Parliament house showing both sides of the senate

items.synopsis: The Senate votes in favour of the Voice to Parliament legislation, finalising the form of the referendum.

title.children: Referendum legislation passes parliament, putting Australia on track for Voice vote

image.altText: The PwC logo is shown on an office building.

items.synopsis: PwC confirms it has been affected by the MOVEit Transfer cyber hack, while the Australian dollar is closing in on 70 US cents as another RBA rate rise is considered a done deal. Follow the latest financial news and analysis on our markets live blog.

title.children: PwC caught up in global data breach, Aussie dollar closes in on 70 US cents, ASX opens higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has ended up posting solid gains, despite falls across the key mining and energy sectors. The ASX 200 index closed 0.6% higher at 7,295 points, while the All Ordinaries gained 0.5% to 7,489. Woolworths (ASX code WOW) was one of the market giants pushing the key indices higher, rising 2.4% to $39.54 after receiving an upgrade to buy from analysts at investment bank UBS. "The sales outlook for Aust Food is positive due to more positive industry drivers and greater confidence that WOW can gain further market share," wrote analyst Shaun Cousins. "Labour costs are rising but well progressed productivity initiatives and operating leverage support EBIT (profit) margin expansion." Despite its share outlook being maintained at neutral by UBS, rival Coles also got a share price boost today up 1.3% to $18.33. The other major weight pulling the market up was a 2.4% rebound for biotech giant CSL to $284.44. The gain today didn't make up for last week's much bigger slide, but was enough to help pull the ASX 200 higher, along with solid rises of 0.8 to 1.5% for the major banks. The big miners and energy firms weighed on the market with moderate declines, such as 1.2% for Rio Tinto, 0.7% for BHP and 0.3% for Woodside. However, many of the smaller players mining lithium or other materials needed for renewable energy took much bigger hits, with Lake Resources (-20%), Liontown Resources (-6%) and Chalice Mining (-5.6%) all down sharply. But old tech fossil fuel miners also got walloped, with coal companies New Hope Corporation (-5.8%) and Whitehaven Coal (-2.9%) also on the nose today. I'm off now and David Chau, who has you covered for 7pm finance tonight, will be back with the markets blog tomorrow morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woolworths lifts ASX on broker upgrade, CSL recovers some ground

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: No, fear not borrowers, it is not a Reserve Bank board meeting date. The next one of those will come on July 4 and, yes, the markets predict there is a better than 50 per cent chance of rates rising. But there is the release of the minutes from the RBA's most recent meeting, where it surprised by raising rates to 4.1% even though the market had priced in less than a 40% chance of rates rising. Those come out at 11:30am AEST. Following that, assistant governor Christopher Kent is part of a panel discussion at a derivatives conference, so probably unlikely to mention too much about rates and the economy. Later in the day, at 1:30pm AEST, deputy governor Michelle Bullock will give a speech on the topic of Achieving Full Employment to the AiGroup (a business group) in Newcastle. That sounds like a topic that will attract a lot more interest, especially given last week's much stronger than expected jobs numbers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA information day tomorrow

featuredLink.title: Economists tip more rate hikes as jobs numbers smash expectations

, where it
surprised by raising rates to 4.1%
even though the market had priced in less than a 40% chance of rates rising.
Those come out at 11:30am AEST.
Following that,
assistant governor Christopher Kent is part of a panel discussion
at a derivatives conference

Later in the day,
at 1:30pm AEST,
deputy governor Michelle Bullock will give a speech
on the topic of Achieving Full Employment
to the AiGroup (a business group) in Newcastle.
That sounds like a topic that will attract a lot more interest, especially given last week's much stronger than expected jobs numbers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: PwC is just the latest global firm to disclose that they have been impacted by the MOVEit Transfer software. Last week, the US Department of Energy and other federal agencies were affected through the file transfer software, while other global companies including Shell, British Airways and the BBC have also fallen victim to the attack. Hackers used a flaw in the MOVEit software to gain access to confidential data, but the Russian-linked group who had previously claimed responsibility hasn't commented on the US or PwC hacks. You can read more about the US federal agencies which have been affected by the hack below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC isn't the only global company caught up in the MOVEit hack

featuredLink.title: US energy department, other federal agencies hit in global hacking spree

children.content: PwC is just the latest global firm to disclose that they have been impacted by the MOVEit Transfer software.

Last week, the US Department of Energy and other federal agencies were affected through the file transfer software, while other global companies including Shell, British Airways and the BBC have also fallen victim to the attack.
Hackers used a flaw in the MOVEit software to gain access to confidential data, but the Russian-linked group who had previously claimed responsibility hasn't commented on the US or PwC hacks.
You can read more about the US federal agencies which have been affected by the hack below:

image.altText: A Ukrainian soldier in a military uniform and helmet stands on the back of a vehicle covered in camouflage.

image.altText: An Indigenous girl with her face dyed all black wearing a colourful feathered headband.

title.children: In an increasingly threatened rainforest, Indigenous teens carry out a rite of passage

image.altText: A green, glowing hospital cross sign outside a pharmacy

items.synopsis: Pharmacists in rural communities say they "won't be able to protect communities" against further medicine shortages from the 60-day prescription scheme as a new report claims huge losses for the industry.

image.altText: A man and a woman walk on beach at sunrise. They are almost silhouetted by the sky behind them.

image.altText: A man in a navy sweater stands in front of a graffiti wall smiling

title.children: Hugh is known as ‘the resilience guy’. Then he ran out of resilience

image.altText: A man reads from paper in front of micrphones with two women either side of him.

items.synopsis: The football club that lost five of its members in last week's Hunter Valley bus crash has spoken publicly for the first time since the tragedy.

title.children: 'Unfathomable heartache': Singleton Roosters speak a week on after fatal Hunter Valley bus crash

image.altText: A greyhound trainer is interviewed on the track.

items.synopsis: Three South Australian greyhound trainers found to have been involved in live baiting are handed life bans from the industry, as well as fined a total of $180,000.

title.children: Life bans, 'largest fines ever' for SA greyhound trainer trio involved in live baiting

image.altText: A man looks dejected after losing a second State of Origin match

title.children: With NSW facing Origin oblivion, can Tedesco summon greatness one more time?

image.altText: A batter walks off dejected as a bowler yells in celebration.

title.children: 'I don't really care': Robinson defends expletive-laden send-off after bowling Khawaja

image.altText: Pat Cummins holds his arms out and looks skyward as Cam Green completes a catch in the foreground

items.synopsis: The rain came in heavy on day three at Edgbaston, but not before Australia unleashed a brief storm of its own to set up a fascinating final two days of the opening Ashes Test.

title.children: Storm clouds inspire Australia's most thrilling spell, and set up potential Edgbaston classic

image.altText: Court hammer and judge in background

items.synopsis: Lies, threats and manipulation — how recordings exposed a rogue expert witness, in a case legal practitioners say is the tip of the iceberg.

title.children: Lies, threats and manipulation: The recordings exposing a court psychologist at work

image.altText: Clear ocean water and a beach with Busselton jetty in the background.

items.synopsis: The South West of WA is one of the most popular destinations in the state, but locals say tourists are prioritised over residents.

title.children: Holiday homes increase in Busselton by 20 per cent in middle of housing crisis

image.altText: RBA governor Philip Lowe speaks at the Morgan Stanley Australia summit in Sydney

items.synopsis: Price caps on gas and energy bill subsidies may be lowering inflation. Can we do more things like that, instead of just raising interest rates?

title.children: Economists tell how to lower inflation without raising interest rates

image.altText: Alexandra Collier, with red lipstick, slight smile, and floral shirt, faces camera in close shot.

items.synopsis: The number of people choosing to start a family on their own is on the rise in Australia. Meet two women who followed different paths into solo parenthood.

title.children: 'I left a very good and happy relationship': Alexandra's partner didn't want a baby, so she did it alone

image.altText: Two middle eastern men embrace as one cries into the other's shoulder.

items.synopsis: As many as 750 men, women and children from Syria, Egypt, the Palestinian territories and Pakistan were on the vessel, trying to reach relatives in Europe.

title.children: Pakistan declares day of mourning for victims of shipwreck off Greece

image.altText: A man looking out the window.

items.synopsis: Pensioner Alan Thiele is not using a heater this winter due to the rising cost of living and site fee increases, which a group of residents are fighting in the New South Wales Civil and Administrative Tribunal.

title.children: 'Cruel and heartless': Residents take park owner to tribunal over soaring site fees

title.children: North Korean officials vow to launch another spy satellite after failed attempt
